block.p: Weeks
This
On
Week
List
FICTION

THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Dell, $7.99.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap for the foreign intelligence service that wants him dead.
MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA, by Arthur Golden. (Vintage, $14.95; $7.99.) A young woman in Kyoto has to reinvent herself after World War II begins.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (Avon, $7.99.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
THE KITE RUNNER, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $15.95 and $14.) An Afghan-American returns to Kabul to learn how his childhood friend has fared under the Taliban.
NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $7.99.) A husband and wife who work for an antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into T.W.A. Flight 800.
LIFE EXPECTANCY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $7.99.) A pastry chef must struggle all his life against a family of evil madmen.
WHITEOUT, by Ken Follett. (Signet, $7.99.) In the middle of a Christmas Eve blizzard in Scotland, a canister filled with a deadly virus goes missing.
BLOOD MEMORY, by Greg Iles. (Pocket Star, $9.95.) A forensic scientist probes recent killings as well as a decades-old crime -- the murder of her father.
WICKED, by Gregory Maguire. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $15.) A little green-skinned girl grows up to become the Wicked Witch of the West; source of the Broadway musical.
TOM CLANCY'S SPLINTER CELL: OPERATION BARRACUDA, by David Michaels. (Berkley, $7.99.) Further adventures of special operative Sam Fisher.
NORTHERN LIGHTS, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $9.99.) In Lunacy, Alaska, the new chief of police finds romance and investigates a murder.
RED LILY, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) A woman who works in a nursery falls in love with the boss's son; conclusion of the ''In the Garden'' trilogy.
LONDON BRIDGES, by James Patterson. (Warner, $7.99.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross contends with two deadly enemies: the Wolf and the Weasel.
LIGHT ON SNOW, by Anita Shreve. (Back Bay Books/Little, Brown, $14.95.) During a New England winter, a girl and her father find an abandoned baby.
SILVER BELLS, by Luanne Rice. (Bantam, $7.50.) A lonely widow and a Christmas tree farmer from Nova Scotia fall in love in New York City at Christmastime.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
NONFICTION
A MILLION LITTLE PIECES, by James Frey. (Anchor, $14.95.) A memoir by a man who was an alcoholic for 10 years and a crack addict for 3.
IN COLD BLOOD, by Truman Capote. (Vintage, $14.) A savage murder in Kansas in 1959 and its consequences.
THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) A journalist's study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
JARHEAD, by Anthony Swofford. (Scribner/Pocket Books, $15 and $7.99.) A memoir of the 1991 Persian Gulf war by a former Marine sniper.
THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $14.95.) The tale of a great architect and a serial killer, who were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
CASH: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY, by Johnny Cash with Patrick Carr. (HarperCollins, $7.99.) The life of country music's Man in Black, who died in 2003.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Broadway, $11.95.) The author, a sportswriter, tells of his visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
WHEN WILL JESUS BRING THE PORK CHOPS?, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $13.95.) Another volume of observations and opinions from the stand-up comedian.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $14.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.
READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) A memoir of a teacher's life in Iran, centered on a women's reading group she organized.
THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE OFFICIAL ILLUSTRATED MOVIE COMPANION, by Perry Moore. (HarperSanFrancisco, $19.95.) A behind-the-scenes look at the making of the movie.
THE KNOW-IT-ALL, by A. J. Jacobs. (Simon & Schuster, $14.) A humorous attempt to become ''the smartest person in the world'' by reading all 32 volumes of the Encylopaedia Britannica.
HIS EXCELLENCY: GEORGE WASHINGTON, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Vintage, $15.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
THE END OF FAITH, by Sam Harris. (Norton, $13.95.) The clash between reason and religion in the modern world.
GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEL, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $16.95.) An argument that Western dominance is due to geographical advantages.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
365: NO REPEATS, by Rachael Ray. (Clarkson Potter, $19.95.) A year's worth of dinner recipes from the Food Channel host.
WHY DO MEN HAVE NIPPLES? by Mark Leyner and Billy Goldberg. (Three Rivers, $12.95.) Humorous answers to medical questions.
THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 2006. (World Almanac, $12.95). The latest edition of a reference work issued annually since 1868.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR FOR KIDS, by Bill O'Reilly and Charles Flowers. (Harper/HarperCollins, $13.95.) Advice for teenagers on sex, drugs and money.
BAD CAT, by Jim Edgar. (Workman, $9.95.) The feline dark side, depicted in humorous pictures and captions.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
NATURAL CURES ''THEY'' DON'T WANT YOU TO KNOW ABOUT, by Kevin Trudeau. (Alliance Publishing Group, $29.95.) Remedies that do not include drugs or surgery. ()
HEALTHY AGING, by Andrew Weil. (Knopf, $27.95.) A doctor explains how the body ages, and describes how diet, activity and attitude can promote longevity.
GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS 2006. (Guinness, $27.95.) A profusely illustrated collection of records about subjects as various as sports and technology.
YOUR BEST LIFE NOW, by Joel Osteen. (Warner Faith, $19.99.) A faith-based approach to living. ()
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) The meaning of life through God. ()

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Nov. 26, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
